pages.text: If you want to protect an area from people griefing you, you can use the $(thing)Security Station/$.$(p)This device prevents all player interaction by untrusted players on blocks within its range. This means that no inventories or GUIs can be opened, and no blocks can be placed or broken.

This sounds great, but to set up a $(thing)Security Station/$ you need to do some things to ensure its security. Because the thing is, $(thing)Security Stations/$ can be $(l:machines/security_station#hacking)hacked/$. The hacking system of the Security Station is heavily inspired by $(l:https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=nQ0rPLlU8v4)Deus Ex: Revolution's hacking system/$.

To set up a $(thing)Security Station/$, you need to place $(l:components/network_components)Network Components/$ in the network grid to form a $(thing)network/$. In every network there should be one $(l:components/network_components#diagnostic)Diagnostic Subroutine/$, one $(l:components/network_components#io_port)Network IO Port/$, and one $(l:components/network_components#registry)Network Registry/$.$(p)These three must all be connected with each other, and you can do that with $(l:components/network_components#node)Network Nodes/$. Placing components in stacks larger than one  increase the $(italic)node rating/$, meaning it will take longer for a $(l:machines/security_station#hacking)hacker/$ (and the $(l:components/network_components#diagnostic)Subroutine/$) to capture it.

pages.title: Upgrades
pages.text: The $(thing)Security Station/$ takes a few upgrades:$(li)$(l:base_concepts/upgrades#entity_tracker)Entity Trackers/$ increase the chance for the $(l:machines/security_station#hacking)hacker/$ to be detected by 20% per upgrade.$(li)$(l:base_concepts/upgrades#security)Security Upgrades/$ increase the number of $(thing)Security Upgrades/$ that hackers need in their $(l:armor/pneumatic_helmet)Pneumatic Helmet/$ to start hacking.$(li)$(l:base_concepts/upgrades#range)Range Upgrades/$ increase the protected range of the station by 1 per upgrade, to a maximum of 16 blocks.

pages.title: Allowing Friends
pages.text: You can add friendly players to your $(thing)Security Station/$ to allow them to interact within the protected area; use the $(bold)Shared Users/$ side tab to enter player names.$(p)You can remove trusted players here too; just click the player's name to remove it.

pages.title: Getting Hacked
pages.text: When someone hacks your $(thing)Security Station/$, you can see that in the $(bold)Problems/$ and $(bold)Status/$ tabs, where it also shows $(italic)who/$ has hacked your system. These players (and only these players) can now interact with blocks within the area. To restore security, you'll have to $(italic)reboot/$ the $(thing)Security Station/$ via the $(bold)Reboot/$ button in the GUI. The reboot process takes 60 seconds, during which time the area isn't secured at all.

pages.title: Hacking
pages.text: To open a $(thing)Security Station/$ that isn't yours, you need a $(l:armor/pneumatic_helmet)Pneumatic Helmet/$ with a $(l:base_concepts/upgrades#security)Security Upgrade/$ installed. When you do this, a GUI similar to the one opposite appears. Watch $(l:https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Lgmpslbrrwo)this video (very old but still relevant)/$ for a guide on how to hack.$(p)To capture a node, $(thing)left-click/$ it. To fortify a captured node, $(thing)right-click/$ it.

pages.title: Tips
pages.text: $(li)Keep your $(thing)Security Station/$ well-concealed and well-protected.$(li)You can protect an area with multiple $(thing)Security Stations/$; all of them must be hacked.$(li)Consider active defences, such as $(l:tools/drone)Drones/$ with combat programs, or $(l:machines/sentry_turret)Sentry Turrets/$$(li)A hacked $(thing)Security Station/$ can be made to emit a $(#f00)redstone signal/$, which could trigger additional measures (TNT under the station, perhaps?)
